internal and external to it. A vertical section of the disk such as is
shown in Plate II Figs 3,4, exhibits the same arrangement under a
different aspect. The <s>shells</s> cells of the concentric zones are seen to be much
higher than they are broad, so that they present a somewhat columnar form,
the proportion of their height to their breadth, however, may vary greatly
in different parts of the same disk, the former often increasing from the
centre towards the periphery, (Fig. 4), whilst the latter remains constant or
nearly so (Fig. 3), and the columns, instead of being straight, are often
more or less curved, and are sometimes bent in the middle of an <s>acute</s> obtuse
angle (Plate VIII, Fig 4, <u>a b</u>) The gradation which presents itself from
one of these forms to the other, and their coexistence even in the same
specimens, clearly proves that no value can be attached to the form
and proportions of the cells, thus seen in a vertical section, as
furnishing specific characters. In every complete specimen, the
columnar cells are seen to be closed at their two extremities by a thin
<s>[?]</u> shelly wall; and this is sometimes flat, sometimes more or less convex.
<u>Note</u> In a large proportion of the specimens obtained from sands
or dredgings, the cells <s>are</s> have been laid-open by attrition; either throughout the
surface of the disk, if it should be flat; or at <s>the</s> its margin only, if it should
